name: Hilton Inn at Penn

reviews.title: Nice for short stays, but lacking in areas.
reviews.text: This property looks pretty new (as of 2008) with this faux-Frank Lloyd Wright concept. The room was comfortable and clean. The location is great (at least in summer when school is out). I'd rank this property very highly, except some significant amenities you'd expect out of a hotel of this class were missing. I think this is the first hotel I've stayed in that didn't provide a hair dryer. There was no pool and they only appear to offer valet parking. The remote was pretty raggedy and the batteries were almost dead. There is a refrigerator in the room, which is a nice thing to have, except on check-in they advise you not to open it or move anything or else you'll get charged an arm and a leg for a soda or a candy bar. They really pushed their restaurants when I checked in as well. I kind of felt like I was being nickeled and dimed on everything, but maybe that's industry standard these days. I'd stay here again for a night or two but I'd look elsewhere for longer stays.

reviews.title: Nice option on campus
reviews.text: Stayed here while at Penn on business - I found the staff very friendly and accommodating, the location excellent in University City and the room clean and comfortable. The bookstore is close by for browsing, and there are great restaurants. The entrance is basically in the "back" of the hotel from where you might expect it, and a second set of elevators or stairs are required to get to the "main floor" - this is a little inconvenient but a minor problem. The bathroom was well stocked and the towels were thick and nice.

reviews.title: Perfect for Visiting Penn
reviews.text: If you are traveling to visit the University of Pennsylvania this is the perfect place to stay. The hotel is directly across the street from the heart of the University and gives you a great snapshot of Penn.

reviews.title: Stunningly beautiful
reviews.text: If you're visiting Penn and don't want to get a rental car, this hotel is very easy to access from the airport via public transportation (if you have bit of time). From the Airport you can take the R1 train to the 30th street station. From there you can go across the street and take a trolly to the 36th street station which is right next to the hotel. The total cost should be under $10.

reviews.title: A nice hotel
reviews.text: This is my second time to stay at the hotel. The previous visit was during the hotel's renovation. The project is complete and the hotel looks very nice.
The location is great. This is not a 5 star hotel (obviously!) but an excellent 4 star hotel. It is high tech and green. The rooms come with iPads which is a nice touch.
reviews.title: Location can't be beat if you have UPenn business

reviews.text: This Hilton serves the UPenn community and is part of a full multi/use block developed along Walnut Street directly across from the Penn Campus (which inlcudes the main book store). Definitely convenient for campus/student visits but we have found it hard to book in the past when Penn is hosting events/conferences and holding blocks of rooms. I think they charge a permium here relative to the other hotel in the neighborhood with not much value added. So don't be disappointed if you can't get in here. You might pay less in Center City which has much more to offer in the way of restarants, etc. and is a short cab or bus ride away. Rooms here are standard for a new Hilton, quiet, ipad technology to summon meals, etc. (We never did get our extra pillows, although the Ipad said we did?!).
reviews.title: Just OK

reviews.text: My husband, son, and I stayed at this hotel during a college tour visit. We were in Philadelphia to look at Drexel University and decided to stay across the street on the U of Penn campus.
reviews.title: Great stay, wonderful breakfast

reviews.text: The hotel is in a downtown location. Parking was $39 for the night. When we checked in, the front desk clerk acknowledged my husband's previous stay. Our room included two free breakfasts but since we had our son with us, she gave us an extra coupon for breakfast so the 3 of us could eat. This was very much appreciated.
reviews.title: Didn't want to leave

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The room had two double beds which served our purpose. The room was recently re-done and looked great. A robe and some chocolates were on one of the beds which had been turned down. The bathroom was large and was stocked with supplies.
reviews.title: Excellent at first glance...

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is a very nice Hilton property in the University district of Philadelphia...but only a 10 minute drive to the historic areas near downtown. The hotel has a charming art deco feel, and the room was large, clean, and nicely decorated. I love the white down comforters I've seen at the last few Hiltons I've stayed in. It's very easy to see how clean they are (which is always nice in light of the occasional television news reports that remind us what DNA-encrusted nightmares most hotel bedspreads are), and (lest you think they are stark) they are dressed up with a rich looking coverlet that you can remove at bedtime. We had a very comfortable king-sized bed, a large armoire with television, minibar, a very roomy desk w/ office chair, and a sitting chair w/ ottoman. The bathroom was also roomy, and had plenty of counterspace surrounding the single sink, a standard tub, and shower. Plush bathrobes were also provided, which were very cozy and must've weighed 20 lbs. apiece. Coffee in the room was a better-than average brand, and real creamers were provided...a nice touch. Godiva chocolates, bottled water, and a fresh bag of ice were delivered at turndown time. There was not mini-fridge in the room, but they are available at no charge upon request...one was delivered to us within 10 minutes after a quick call to the front desk.
reviews.title: Very Nice

likes.liked: — Cleanlienss, attractive comfy rooms, excellent staff.

reviews.title: Newer and better
reviews.text: One of the nicest things about the hotel was the service. All staff members we encountered, from concierge to valet parking attendants, were highly professional, very courteous, friendly, and helpful. Another thing I loved was the quiet. The sound-dampening must be very good in the hotel, because I never heard a sound at night...either from the adjacent rooms and hallway or the streets below.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There's a small, cozy lounge in the hotel, which is where breakfast is also served every morning. We did not try either, but did go to the hotel's attached wine bar and restaurant (Penne Restaurant and Wine Bar) one night. We found the wine-by-the-glass selection there to be limited and overpriced, and the menu selections uninspiring, so we moved on.
reviews.title: The bed of my dreams

likes.disliked: — Lack of a free fridge, being next to the elevators

reviews.title: Very Good Experience at the Hilton at Penn
reviews.text: The only negative experience occurred when the housekeeping staff failed to close our door completely after servicing the room. one day. Nothing was taken, but it was a bit unnerving to return to the hotel in the early evening to find our door slightly ajar.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I recommend this hotel for its service, comfort, and attractive decor...but at rates of approximately $200+ per night along with valet parking charges of $27/day (there is no self-parking on the property, or anywhere nearby that I could see), you will pay for that.
reviews.title: Great hotel, reasonable location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed here for one night this September when we saw Interpol play at the Tower Theatre. We chose this theatre because of the positive reviews, its proximity to the theatre and its price. The hotel's location is beautiful - very close (basically inside) the U of Penn campus. Walking distance to many nice restaurants (we ate at the very mod 'POD' which is right on the corner, and White Dog - recommend both) and shops. It's odd that you climb stairs to get to the check in desk, but everyone is very courteous and professional. The hotel is not art deco (1930's sleek), but it is Arts and Crafts (think Frank Lloyd Wright) - huge difference. There are oak details everywhere and it feels homey and comfortable. The room is spacious with updated baths and comfortable beds with feather tops and feather pillows. The furniture is also updated and continues the Arts and Crafts theme. No cheap, dented furniture here. We were impressed what we got for the money. weird: we wanted to refrigerate some fruit we brought, but learned on this website that if you use the fridge, you get charged even if you don't eat anything! there is a sensor in the fridge that charges you if you move anything. absolutely ridiculous. You can request a separate fridge for the room, but come on. Just count the snacks in the fridge like everyone else. Anyway, if you are in town to go downtown to museums and the waterfront, it will be a bit of a trek since this hotel is across the river and not that close to public transportation. We drove 10 minutes to the theatre for the show, which was fantastic but in a lousy part of town, and drove back. If we were coming to visit Philly, we would return to the Four Seasons, the Rittenhosue or somewhere closer to town. But, if we travel here for a show again, we would definitely stay here again. Great place to stay in this side of town (and if our kids wind up going to school here, this is where we'll stay!)
reviews.title: Hilton Penn a comfortable, affordable choice

reviews.text: Stay in Philly 1 to 2 times per year for eight years. Couryard by Marriott is the only hotel we have been to more than once until we found the Inn at Penn. It is a VERY NICE hotel. We would prefer a wonderful B&B but can not find one in Philly. This hotel is the next best thing. IT is small, intimate. Front desk welcomes you as if you belong. They know your name and use it as you come and go. Very warm, warm atmosphere. Nicely appointed rooms. Great beds. Super good Italian Restaurant. Walkable location for business in that particular end of town. All around NICE PLACE. We will go back again and again.
reviews.title: Among the best Philly has to offer

likes.liked: — Warm feeling of staff and decor
likes.disliked: — Some detail follow-up; but they corrected it

reviews.text: As one poster noted previously, this is a great location when visiting students at UPenn or Drexel, but it is a distance from the city and tourist areas. The station for the underground "trolley" is only two blocks away, so it's easy to get downtown for a $2 fare.
reviews.title: A very pleasant stay

likes.liked: — location for visiting family member at UPenn
likes.disliked: — distance from downtown and Penn's Landing

reviews.text: The hotel is lovely, with an art deco interior. The staff are helpful and accommodating. Rooms are spacious and comfortable.
reviews.title: lovely hotel - zero service

reviews.text: I did not eat at the restaurant (Penne) but did have breakfast in the lovely University Club, which provided the option of a cold ($11) or hot ($14) buffet.
reviews.title: Worth The Money

reviews.text: My daughter and I stayed at this property during the admitted students' day at UPenn. As a Hilton Diamond member we were upgraded to one of their circular suites which was huge and lovely and modern. It had a living room/dining room, mini bar area with fridge and microwave, a huge bedroom and bathroom, and windows all around in a circular shape. It also had an IPad in the room. This must be one of the nicest rooms I have ever stayed in and the reception staff were extremely nice and helpful. Ms. Kenyatta was the lovely lady who helped me and was in touch to see if we needed anything. We greatly enjoyed our stay and hope to be back soon.
reviews.title: One of the nicest hotels I have stayed in

reviews.text: What an amazing hotel with extraordinary service. Friendly staff, they upgraded me to a corner suite with separate living/dining room. Very clean. Very new. And very innovative lighting/hvac controls with iPad in every room to request services. I'll be back to this property; it's now at the top of my Philly list.
reviews.title: Amazing...best hotel stay in Philadelphia ever

reviews.text: I usually avoid hiltons because I have found the Front desk staff to be rather rude and inattentive in my prior encounters. The Inn at PENN is a sharp break from my prior experience. A nice facility, great location for visiting PENN, and everyone I met was helpful, friendly and showed genuine concern. I will be Back!
reviews.title: Nice clean rooms, Very pleasent desk staff.
Really like this hotel
reviews.text: We use this hotel when we visit U. Penn. I have enjoyed it every time. The parking is not cheap but the location of the hotel is excellent. The staff is always so friendly and the rooms are very clean. The beds are comfortable. Breakfast was very good and not at all crowded. Wi-Fi included is a nice bonus. I will stay here again.
Nice facility and response staff for a business meeting. Our meeting room was flooded due to a broken pipe overnight, and the hotel staff was able to relocate us on very short notice.
reviews.title: Good Hotel for a Business Meeting
Nearly but not quite perfect
reviews.text: "Hilton Inn at Penn" is a bit misleading; it's the Inn at Penn and it's run by Hilton, and if anything that's even better. Trust that if the University of Pennsylvania owns something, it will be done right--and this hotel is no exception. As others have noted, the elegant and understated Arts & Crafts furnishings and the proximity to Penn are big pluses, and as someone who obsesses over the rock-like pillows offered by too many hotels, I was delighted to find five feather- and down-stuffed pillows on my king-size bed. (An email received a few days before my stay actually offered substitute types of pillows if I'd preferred--another thoughtful touch.) This hotel is also the repository of Penn's excellent collection of unintentionally (or was it?) homoerotic athletic statuary by the noted sculptor R. Tait McKenzie. All well and good, but when a traveler's flight is three hours late and he checks in, very weary, at 3 a.m., it's cruel in the extreme for the front desk to assign him to a room next to the hotel fitness center. I was too bleary-eyed to take note of this in the middle of the night, but starting at 6 a.m. it was all clanking freeweights and blaring CNN from the fitness center TVs. Another ding: the hotel's extremely friendly and efficient staff seems constantly in motion through the hallways, yammering on walkie-talkies. They are undoubtedly busy taking care of details and heading off problems, which is admirable, but perhaps they can be told to keep their voices down. I report all of this with some regret, as in most ways this is an unusually *quiet* hotel, and so utterly comfortable that most travelers will surely have no reason to complain. But best to keep hotels on their toes--that's what Tripadvisor is partly about, after all.

reviews.title: Top notch service; perfect for campus visit
reviews.text: FYI, the Inn at Penn is not only convenient to the University of Pennsylvania and Drexel University but also to Amtrak's 30th Street Station (the main station in Philadelphia), and if, like me, you happen to arrive at 3 a.m. you'll find yourself no more than 10 minutes from the airport (it could easily be a half hour at other times). Center City Philadelphia can be reached more economically by bus or "subway-surface" trolley cars than by taxis; buses run downtown on Chestnut St. (a half block north of the hotel) and subway-surface cars board underground on 36th St. If you're a good walker and unencumbered by bags, you can be in the heart of Center City within a half hour. If you like to dine with live music, check out the World Cafe in the studios of WXPN, Penn's NPR-affiliated radio station, possibly the only case of a radio program turning into a restaurant. Penn's interesting little Institute for Contemporary Art is practically next to the Inn and the outstanding University Museum (one of the world's great archaeology museums) is located just a few blocks across campus.

reviews.title: Pricey but nicey
reviews.text: We found the Inn at Penn through the "One Big Campus" website promoting Philly-area colleges. The 'discounted' rate of $225 was the same as the Expedia rate, but no matter, it was good value for the money. Exceptionally courteous reception from bellman and valet parking guy. Room was clean, with nice mission-style furniture and the upgraded bedding that seems to be the hot thing right now. The 'library' sitting room offered fireplaces and the Financial Times. The bellman tipped us off to the outstanding "White Dog Cafe" restaurant down the street. The hotel's breafast buffet was much above average. And when it was time to leave, the concierge desk had pre-printed driving directions to all the area colleges.

reviews.title: really fine
reviews.text: This is easily the nicest hotel in University City, but also the priciest. If you can afford it, the convenience to Penn can't be beat. The hotel and rooms are comfortable, staff is great. The style is mostly authentic mission, much better than most chains. Public spaces include a nice library/bar. Hilton will also take internet advance requests for special amenities like pillows, room service when you arrive, etc. that helps make a late night business trip arrival relaxing.

reviews.title: Amazing Quaint Hotel
reviews.text: we came there in the afternoon and the staff was really nice. it's a good hotel for a city trip. central and quite.

The location of this hotel if you are visiting Penn is fantastic. The hotel itself looks pretty good on the surface. The lobby and restaurant are attractive if a little fussy in that typical hotel style. Our room was nice too. In particular, the bathroom was much nicer than your typical Hilton, and had just recently been redone. Great lighting in the bathroom, and everything felt clean and fresh in there. The rest of the room, however, suffered from negligent maintenance. Our remote control really looked disgusting, and there was a just a general feeling that things had not been cleaned adequately.
reviews.title: Great if you need to be at Penn
Great getaway!!
reviews.text: I sampled the restaurant for breakfast, and after the great reviews on Trip Advisor, I expected a lot. However, I was really disappointed on every front, except that the room itself was quite nice looking. The food wasn't up to snuff, however. First, no cappuccino machine. In a hotel in this price category and location, I really expect them to offer this. Second, the buffet was disappointing. Although it was literally empty, I had to wait several minutes to be acknowledged by the lady cooking the omelets, which was aggravating. No greeting when I walked up even though no one else was around. It was only when I started to get scrambled eggs, as I was tired of waiting, that she decided to say something. I said that I was tired of waiting, and she disputed that I had waited at all. I don't need to get into an argument first thing in the morning about how much time I spent waiting. How about a greeting when the customer steps up and a "I'll be with you shortly". The rest of the buffet looked fairly average, although there was a decent croissant, surprisingly. But I wouldn't bother with this next time.

I would probably only give this hotel three stars, but there was a great gym, and that pushed it into the four star category for me. It was a much nicer gym that almost anything I have seen in this price category, and it was open 24 hours a day. Big plus!! One more thing that was nice was that they gave me noon checkout with no problem whatsoever, which was much appreciated. I would stay here again, but I would just lower my expectations a notch.
reviews.title: Not pricey....this is the place where the meaning, You get what you pay for, was derived

reviews.text: We live only 30 minutes outside the city but stayed here for the Dionne Warwick concert at the Annenberg. The service was perfect from the vallet, reception desk and especially Bessie the Concierge who knows everything about the city and issuch a pleasant person to deal with. Our room was exceptionally clean and had been recently upgraded from top to bottom. The iPad in each room is also a nice touch. All in all it was a delightful stay and I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting the city.
reviews.title: Nice stay

reviews.text: Sue and Andy
reviews.title: Great hotel, perfect for Penn visits

reviews.text: There are three places to stay at the campus of the University of Pennsylvania: Penn Towers, the Sheraton, and Hilton's Inn At Penn. Having stayed at all three, I found the Inn to be the best choice.
reviews.title: Best Place to Stay at Penn Campus

reviews.text: The Penn Towers used to be a Hilton until the University Hospital bought the building and converted most of it to office space. They kept a couple floors as guest rooms for families of patients but the rooms were in serious need of refurbishing last time I stayed. The Sheraton is a bit old but certainly okay. The Inn is only about fifteen years old and while certainly not a FIve-Star hotel, gets four stars in my book. The staff is helpful, the furnishings nice, and each room has an iPad with an Internet connection and HD television. Also, the restaurant was pretty good - just a step below the White Dog a block away which is the best restaurant on campus.
reviews.title: I love this place!

reviews.text: The only drawback I could note was that our bathroom had only a fancy shower stall, no tub if you want to take a bath. Also, all parking is by valet for an extra nightly fee and I believe cars are actually parked in the University parking garage a block away.
reviews.title: Excellent service and accomodations

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Note that for certain University events, the university controls a room block for all or most of the rooms. For example, I stayed during the Penn Relays track & field meet when the rooms were only available to certain teams or officials at the meet and not the general public. The room rate for the weekend was close to the Sheraton's. I would expect it to be somewhat higher in typical weeks. But it is a nicer hotel.
reviews.title: A bit dated in communal areas but nice rooms and in a good location.

reviews.text: I love this hotel! Its location is perfect, its tons of places to eat in the area, and the staff is so friendly. I've stayed at this hotel about 20 times in the last year and everytime I've never regreted it. The only semi bad things is that it doesnt have a pool:( and also the corners of the bed are kind of sharp, but I'm a little clumsy. I brought my two children with me for each stay and they're under 5 and we never received a single complaint about noise. The only person at the hotel that was a "problem" was the older lady at the breakfast buffet. She isnt a good multi tasker. But with that said, I love this hotel, super friendly staff, and the breakfast buffet is one the best I've ever had, and I'm a world traveler, who is orginaly from Guam. Stay here everyone is super nice from the time you pull into the valet, from the time you leave.
reviews.title: Great Choice If You're Staying In The City

aka: Hilton Inn At Penn Hotel Philadelphia
description: The Inn at Penn is a traditional hotel with a contemporary twist. Our newly renovated AAA Four-Diamond hotel is located on the campus of the University of Pennsylvania and is walking distance to shopping, restaurants and the great nightlife that Center City Philadelphia boasts. Complimentary wireless Internet is available throughout the hotel as well as an iPad in every guestroom plus PURE (hypo-allergenic) rooms, media hubs, refrigerators, and luxurious bath amenities are all included in our guestrooms.
